title: For Fellowkids Studio Kiln Shows How Brands Can Behave Like Fans
source_credit: Work by For Fellowkids via The Brand Identity
summary: Studio Kiln revitalized Fellowkids' identity, an agency navigating the esports and entertainment landscape. The sophisticated new branding mirrors genuine fan engagement, shifting from passive observer to active participant. Central to this is the adaptable "Fellowkid" character, initially conceived as a collectible 3D art toy, alongside a dynamic Y2K-inspired visual system and bespoke typography. This multi-faceted approach ensures the brand resonates authentically within diverse communities, reflecting its evolving ambitions.
fullContent:
Fellowkids, an agency renowned for cultivating fervent communities and cultural resonance for others, found its own identity lagging behind its growth and sophisticated clientele. Their inherent "rock and roll" spirit and ambitious work demanded a visual language that transcended previous iterations, capable of high-stakes pitches and reflecting their commitment to serious playfulness without corporate pretense. Studio Kiln’s response was rooted in a profound insight: if Fellowkids orchestrates fandom, its own brand must authentically embody the spirit of a fan – agile, responsive, and deeply integrated within its community, not a performative facade.

This foundational thinking manifested in the "Fellowkid" – a hooded figure, the identity's emotional linchpin. Recognizing the hoodie as a universal signifier of belonging across diverse cultures, Studio Kiln placed this archetypal fan at the brand's heart. Innovatively, the Fellowkid was conceived as a 3D physical vinyl art toy from the outset, underscoring the brand's tangible collectibility. This distinctive, adaptable silhouette allows the Fellowkid to seamlessly shift allegiances, adopting diverse colors, textures, and graphics to represent myriad teams and moments, embodying "one figure, infinite identities."

Around this central character, Studio Kiln meticulously built a Y2K-inspired visual universe, drawing from nostalgic tech aesthetics like translucent plastics, candy-brights, saturated neons, and deep blacks. This dynamic palette flexes from "loud" hype moments to grounded sophistication with softer hardware greys. The typography system balances bespoke, Y2K-flavored elements with the clarity and neutrality of Aeonik, anchored by Aeonik Mono for technical detailing. This modular "digital sticker sheet" approach empowers the Fellowkids team to create engaging assets quickly, cultivating a rich yet flexible brand experience.

The rebrand's impact was immediate and transformative. Clients explicitly praised the refreshed identity’s fun, bright, and exciting presentation, directly contributing to pitch successes. The tangible Fellowkid vinyl toy, in particular, resonated deeply, lauded as playful yet premium, collectible yet accessible – perfectly mirroring Fellowkids' own values. This strategic evolution not only elevated their external perception but also internally empowered the agency, aligning its visual presence with its 'rock and roll' ethos and authentic engagement, transforming the brand into something people actively root for.

title: How Kimera Built Cursors Identity Around A Custom Typeface System
source_credit: Work by How Kimera via The Brand Identity
summary: We orchestrated a holistic brand evolution for Cursor, an AI code editor for professional developers. Central to this refresh was Cursor Gothic, a bespoke typographic system rooted in Waldenburg. This custom font seamlessly integrates sophisticated logo ligatures and an extensive icon set, alongside a dedicated monospace variant for the code editor. Our design strategy ensured cohesive typographic integrity across all brand and product interfaces, balancing technical prowess with human-centric design.
fullContent:
Here's a comprehensive and engaging narrative about the Cursor branding project:

Cursor, a prominent type foundry specializing in an innovative code editor, tasked Kimera with evolving, not reinventing, its brand identity. The core challenge involved refining Ben Barry’s original logo for versatility and screen optimization, balancing high-end technical sophistication with an inviting, human warmth. With an enthusiastic community and significant existing equity, the goal was strategic refinement – "fewer but better" – creating a robust foundation. This project sought seamless integration across brand and product touchpoints, including the code editor itself, leveraging established elements to fortify Cursor’s position.

Kimera’s solution centered on Cursor Gothic, a bespoke typeface meticulously crafted from their acclaimed Waldenburg. Valued for its blend of Akzidenz-Grotesk’s rationality and Univers’ analogue warmth, Waldenburg was the ideal starting point. Kimera condensed the letterforms, accentuating squarish shapes and heightening contrast for smoother rhythm in text. A true innovation lies in "logo ligatures": embedding Cursor’s logotypes directly within the typeface. This ensures optical perfection over mathematical centering, collapsing the boundary between brand communication and typography, and anticipating the typeface's adaptation into a monospace version for the actual code editor.

This holistic design philosophy extended to every element. Custom icons, developed for seamless function across website UI and the code editor, incorporated rounded caps and corners for optimal screen performance and visual consistency. The iconic cube logo, evolved from Ben Barry’s original, extended into three versions, with geometric purity yielding to optical truth for small-scale clarity. The distinctive color palette further sets Cursor apart, adopting a nuanced warm undertone and an accent orange from industrial tools, reinforcing its robust yet human positioning. The website serves as an immersive experience, integrating interactive product elements that dynamically replicate the desktop app's behavior.

Described by Justin Jay Wang as an expression of Cursor's existing identity rather than a transformation, this comprehensive refresh establishes a robust, adaptive foundation. By refining core strengths and leveraging brand equity, Kimera crafted an identity that is both cohesive and deeply functional. The forthcoming Cursor Mono, a monospace extension for the code editor, will complete this ambitious integration. The project powerfully demonstrates the profound impact achieved when brand and product design converge through a unified typographic language, creating unparalleled consistency and synergy across every touchpoint.

title: How Wedge Shifted Allergen Brand Growhappy From Fear To Confidence
source_credit: Work by How Wedge via The Brand Identity
summary: Our strategic repositioning for GrowHappy, an early allergen introduction brand, redefined a category fraught with parental anxiety. We established "ImmunoNutrition" to underscore immune system development, moving beyond fear-based narratives. The comprehensive visual identity departs from clinical norms, embracing a warm, storybook-inspired aesthetic through soft palettes and approachable typography. This empowers parents with confidence and promotes food freedom, leading with science and design-driven reassurance.
fullContent:
The emergence of GrowHappy addresses a crucial disconnect: the chasm between robust scientific evidence advocating early allergen introduction and the widespread parental anxiety surrounding it. Founded by Stephanie Wibom, whose personal journey began after her daughter's allergic reaction, the brand collaborated with leading pediatric allergen experts, including Dr. Carina Venter, to translate prevention guidelines into actionable solutions. Yet, in a market saturated with fear-based messaging and clinical aesthetics, simply stating the science was insufficient. Independent creative studio Wedge was tasked with a demanding brief: to craft a brand identity that not only strategically repositioned the approach to allergen introduction but fundamentally shifted parents' mindsets from apprehension to proactive confidence.

Wedge's strategic breakthrough began with language itself, moving beyond the industry's fear-mongering narrative. They ingeniously coined a new category: "ImmunoNutrition." This term masterfully reframes early allergen exposure, shifting the perception from a risky endeavor to a vital act of nourishing and building the immune system. This semantic innovation immediately differentiates GrowHappy, positioning it not against fear, but as a leader in a proactive health space. The accompanying product line, "ImmunoButters," succinctly communicates both the format and the core benefits, making the concept immediately digestible and approachable for parents. This carefully crafted nomenclature establishes GrowHappy as an authoritative, yet empathetic, guide, empowering parents with "food freedom" through clear science and a positive outlook.

The visual language developed by Wedge deliberately eschews typical pharmaceutical or clinical aesthetics, drawing instead from the reassuring world of storybooks and classic baby products. This psychological approach aims to calm anxious parents, offering a gentle embrace rather than stark medical reminders. The palette features soft, muted tones, a calming departure from the bold primaries or sterile whites common in the category. Typography balances clarity and warmth, conveying expertise without intimidation. A standout element is the illustration style, inspired by vintage botanical fruit-and-vegetable plates. This choice is multifunctional: visually anchoring products in whole-food nutrition, evoking heritage and trustworthiness, and providing a subtle, educational quality. Every detail, from these illustrations to the intuitive information architecture, was meticulously designed to make parents feel capable and informed, transforming a potentially stressful act into a confident step. Stephanie Wibom’s personal insights further ensured this empathetic balance.

The culmination of this strategic and empathetic branding effort is a GrowHappy that stands as both an expert guide and a deeply understanding companion. By deliberately avoiding clinical or fear-driven visuals and instead embracing soft, organized, and reassuring touchpoints, the design instills immediate comprehension and confidence. Parents instantly grasp the product's purpose and significance, fostering trust through clarity rather than coercion. The brand successfully reframes allergens not as threats, but as essential components of a wholesome diet critical for immune health and gut development. Launched on Mother’s Day and Allergy Awareness Week, GrowHappy proudly pioneers the newly defined ImmunoNutrition category, creating a vital space for a paradigm shift. Wedge’s thoughtful integration of strategic language and a warm visual system empowers parents to view early allergen introduction as an act of nourishment, fostering courage over fear in their child’s nutritional journey.

title: Los Yorks Pixel Based System Gives Netflixs Eyeline A Bold New Vision
source_credit: Work by Los Yorks via The Brand Identity
summary: For Eyeline, Netflix's premiere VFX partner, we engineered a dynamic brand identity reflecting its evolution. The core concept centers on the pixel as an elemental building block, unlocking limitless visual potential. A modular, grid-based system unifies its VFX, Studios, and Labs divisions through an RGB color strategy. Typographic tension between a cinematic serif and modern sans articulates the seamless blend of artistry and engineering, establishing a sophisticated presence beyond industry clichés.
fullContent:
Eyeline, a pioneering force at the intersection of visual effects, studio production, and experimental technology, faced a critical branding challenge: unifying its three distinct divisions under a single, cohesive identity. The goal was to project a forward-looking vision that transcended typical VFX clichés, emphasizing artistic craft and inventive spirit, while operating at a global scale akin to their partner, Netflix. The new identity needed to communicate Eyeline’s unique position where cutting-edge engineering meets boundless imagination, honoring its legacy while defining its future.

Los York answered this complex brief with a deceptively simple yet profoundly powerful concept: the pixel as origin. This foundational idea – the smallest unit of vision, a single spark unlocking infinite potential – served as a perfect metaphor for Eyeline’s work, where technology and creativity are inextricably linked. From this core, a modular and expressive design language unfolded, establishing a shared graphic DNA. Each division then found its unique voice through color: red for Studios, green for VFX, and blue for Labs. Together, these form a complete RGB spectrum, a sophisticated nod to image-making's elemental building blocks, providing distinction within coherence.

The pixel concept evolved into a dynamic, grid-based system, capable of infinite expansion from micro to macro, mirroring Eyeline’s collaborative and adaptable creative process. Typography further reinforced this duality, pairing the cinematic warmth of ITC Garamond Light Narrow with the technical precision and contemporary edge of Netflix Sans. This deliberate contrast symbolizes the brand's core tension: imagination meets engineering, grounding the identity in filmmaking legacy while embracing a forward-facing digital ethos. Crucially, the identity actively eschews the often-flashy aesthetics of the VFX industry, opting instead for a clean, confident frame that allows Eyeline's extraordinary craft to take center stage. The result is an aesthetic that is cinematic yet minimal, expressive yet restrained, designed to showcase thinking over mere technique.

The new identity has been met with widespread acclaim, both internally and across the industry. Eyeline’s leadership lauded Los York for capturing the company's spirit and future trajectory, with CEO Jeffrey Shapiro expressing how it perfectly encapsulated "who we are and where we are headed." This sentiment was echoed by Head of Studios Kevin Baillie, who highlighted the overwhelmingly positive feedback from peers. Ultimately, the project's success lies in its ability to elegantly bridge legacy with innovation, transforming Eyeline into a brand truly defined by imagination—a testament to how every pixel, every design decision, reinforces an ethos where technology fuels limitless possibility.
